channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus in the US: Live Updates
item.description: President Trump announced the plan in a late-night tweet with few details, and it was unclear how many people would be affected. The worldwide death toll from the pandemic is far higher than official counts suggest, according to a Times analysis.

item.title: Roommates in Coronavirus Era: ‘Friends’ It Isn’t
item.description: Living with a roommate has always included some drama. But these days, once petty grievances about cleanliness or visitors have morphed into arguments over safety.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a week of wearing pajamas all day in their Atlanta apartment, Naomi Nagel and Michelle Topping decided they had to do something to force them to change clothes, and to lift their moods. They created a “spirit month” calendar.

item.title: Coronavirus Roommate Tips: The Dos and Don'ts
item.description: In most zombie movies, there’s usually someone who endangers the lot. Don’t let that be you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Arthur Adamczyk shares hand sanitizer with his roommate Nash Petrovic on their rooftop in Brooklyn during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: During Coronavirus, Unions Resist New Demands on Teachers
item.description: Educators say they want to teach from home during the pandemic, but are fighting to limit work hours and counter demands that they consider unreasonable.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Atherton Dukes, an art teacher in Tulsa, Okla., seen here in 2018. She is now juggling care for her two children and responsibilities for her remote classroom.

item.title: The Latest Fashion Accessory in Miami: A Luxury Condo
item.description: Upscale brands are licensing their names to developers in South Florida who are looking to stand out in a crowded market.
item.dc:creator: C. J. Hughes
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fendi collaborated with the interior designer Fanny Haim on the beachfront Fendi Chateau Residences in Surfside, Fla.

item.title: Coronavirus, Immigration, Kim Jong-un: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Past Into Present: 4 Journeys That Changed Us
item.description: We asked four of our contributors to write about trips that shaped who they are today, and that inspire them now, in these housebound days.
item.dc:creator: Ron Stodghill, Charly Wilder, Sarah Khan and Bonnie Tsui

item.title: How The Times Covered the First Earth Day, 50 Years Ago
item.description: For the first Earth Day, on April 22, 1970, The New York Times went big.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: The Sound of One Shrimp Snapping
item.description: How climate change is altering nature’s sonic landscape.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker During Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Global News Tracker
item.description: Hong Kong announced an extension in its restrictions a day after reporting no new cases. And President Trump said he planned to close the United States to people trying to immigrate.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Milan on Sunday. Coronavirus overwhelmed health care systems in the north of Italy.

item.title: Joe Biden Starts General Election Nearly $187 Million Behind Trump
item.description: New fund-raising figures show the depth of the financial hole in which Mr. Biden finds himself against a president and Republican Party that have built up a huge war chest.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a campaign event in McClellanville, S.C., in February.

item.title: Trump Plans to Suspend Immigration to U.S.
item.description: The president portrayed the measure, his most wide-ranging attempt yet to seal off the country from the world, as a bid to save Americans’ jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday at the White House. Late Monday evening, he tweeted that he would sign an “Executive Order to temporarily suspend immigration into the United States!”

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Disputes over testing availability and strategy in the U.S. impeded progress on several fronts.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Abigail Thernstrom, Scholarly Foe of Affirmative Action, Dies at 83
item.description: She supported civil rights, but later, with her husband, Stephan, concluded that colorblind policies worked better than preferential treatment.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Abigail Thernstrom at a Senate subcomittee hearing. An opponent of affirmative action, she was appointed to the United States Commission on Civil Rights by President George W. Bush.

item.title: Doctors and Governors Vie for Coronavirus Masks in Cloak-and-Dagger Deals
item.description: Despite plans to reopen states, equipment to protect workers from the coronavirus remains in high demand. “The need for an organized, equitable distribution system is dire,” a doctor said.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye, Andrew Jacobs, Jo Becker and Tim Arango
item.media:credit: Katherine Taylor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Andrew W. Artenstein, the chief physician executive of Baystate Health in Springfield, Mass., had to go to great lengths to procure urgently needed masks.

item.title: How Abortion, Guns and Church Closings Made Coronavirus a Culture War
item.description: Flattening the curve is now one of the most contentious issues in politics.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.category: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research
item.media:description: People gathered to protest Pennsylvania’s stay-at-home order at the Capitol in Harrisburg on Monday. President Trump has encouraged similar demonstrations in several states.

item.title: Dispute Over Virus Testing Delays Deal on Aid to Small Businesses and Hospitals
item.description: Democrats are insisting that the legislation require the Trump administration to establish a national testing strategy, but the president wants states to take responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drive-through coronavirus testing site in Brooklyn. A dispute over testing is one of the final sticking points before Congress can reach an agreement on a new funding program.

item.title: Georgia, Tennessee and South Carolina Move to Reopen as Hot Spots Emerge
item.description: Even as some states move to restart their economies, coronavirus hot spots are emerging, including at a state prison in Ohio.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Michael Cooper
item.media:description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia listening to a question from the news media during a tour of a temporary hospital at the Georgia World Congress Center last week in Atlanta.

item.title: Trump Exceptionalism
item.description: What happened to President Trump’s approval ratings?
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Michelle Obama Is Reading Books to Children Stuck at Home
item.description: The former first lady said she would share some of her favorite children’s books and try to give families a much-needed break.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: The former first lady Michelle Obama during the “One World: Together at Home” event on Saturday. She started her virtual story time this week.

item.title: Supreme Court Rules Against Landowners in Montana Superfund Fight
item.description: Landowners may not sue the Atlantic Richfield Company to force it to do more than a federal cleanup plan requires unless the Environmental Protection Agency consents, the court ruled.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Walter Hinick/The Montana Standard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In 1983, the area near Butte, Mont., was designated a Superfund site.

item.title: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
item.description: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Matthew Goldstein and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Representative Maxine Waters, the Democratic chairwoman of the House Financial Services Committee, is seeking to aid mortgage servicers.

item.title: Supreme Court Bans Non-Unanimous Jury Verdicts for Serious Crimes
item.description: The badly fractured decision, affecting defendants in two states, continued a debate among the justices over the power of precedent.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The case that the justices decided on was in one sense mere constitutional housekeeping, but a 1972 decision complicated matters.

item.title: Frustrated by Lack of Coronavirus Tests, Maryland Got 500,000 From South Korea
item.description: Facing shortages, Gov. Larry Hogan and his wife, Yumi Hogan, negotiated with suppliers in South Korea to obtain the kits. “It should not have been this difficult,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland said a lack of testing was the “No. 1 problem” facing his state.

item.title: Sirio Maccioni, Whose Le Cirque Drew Manhattan’s Elite, Dies at 88
item.description: Dash, charm and matinee-idol looks helped make Mr. Maccioni an unusual sort of celebrity in New York City’s restaurant scene.
item.dc:creator: William Grimes
item.media:credit: Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sirio Maccioni in 1982. His fine dining restaurants in Manhattan drew an international following that included royalty, film stars, jet-setters and socialites.

item.title: The Pandemic’s Hidden Victims: Sick or Dying, but Not From the Coronavirus
item.description: As the coronavirus overwhelms the health care system, people with other illnesses struggle to find treatment.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Bruce Lowell, an internist in Great Neck, N.Y. “People are still having heart attacks, people are still having strokes,” he said. “I feel as if there is no awareness of anything other than Covid.”

item.title: ‘It’s Really a Gift’: Israeli Hospitals Let Relatives Say Goodbye Up Close
item.description: A hospital spokesman asked why family members were barred from coronavirus wards when journalists could visit in protective gear. His bosses had no good answer.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Rinat Zita-Dishlo, right, saying goodbye to her mother, Batsheva Zita, 74, in the coronavirus ward of the Sourasky Medical Center on Sunday.
